The working of the plan will be
simple. The University will issue,
Without charge, cards of admission

It is planned to'issue season tickets

Who apply to the Director of Athletics. The number of tickets distributed to non-alumni will be limited

Move Continues Policy
This move is a continuation of the
policy adopted several years ago,
When the few existing athletic scholarships were abolished, athletics
brought under the control of the University, and a strong program of intramural sports introduced. At the
same time, the scope of intercollegiate activities was extended to cover
thirteen sports instead of six. There
may be a further extension under the
new plan.
The resu ltls were eminently
satisfactory. Eighty-five per cent of
students engaged in some sort of
athletic activity, instead of a chosen
handful, and there was a lessened
tendency to emphasize the records of
the individual team. But it was still
Incomplete. The final step is the removal of the gate-receipts and guarantees, which at times led to a temptation to schedule games which drew
large crowds with opponents which
hopelessly outclassed Hopkins, and
to accept games with larger teams
for the sake of the fat guarantee, and
providing the other team with a
"breather." However, this has not
been done, and the temptation itself
Is now finally removed.
Just what effect this move will
have on the rating of Hopkins teams
is not known. Under the other plan,
the records have been poor on the surface, because Hopkins could play only
teams of comparable ability, and
chose its teams entirely from the
material which naturally turned out.
However, assuming that the purpose
Of college athletics is to provide
training and physical development for
the students, the plan was a success.
To quote from the report, "There is
reason to believe, however, that with
adequate training and instruction,
Hopkins teams should be equal to
those of other institutions comparable
in size."

Move Continues Policy
This move is a continuation of the
policy adopted several years ago,
When the few existing athletic scholarships were abolished, athletics
brought under the control of the University, and a strong program of intramural sports introduced. At the
same time, the scope of intercollegiate activities was extended to cover
thirteen sports instead of six. There
may be a further extension under the
new plan.

satisfactory. Eighty-five per cent of
students engaged in some sort of
athletic activity, instead of a chosen
handful, and there was a lessened
tendency to emphasize the records of
the individual team. But it was still
Incomplete. The final step is the removal of the gate-receipts and guarantees, which at times led to a temptation to schedule games which drew
large crowds with opponents which
hopelessly outclassed Hopkins, and
to accept games with larger teams
for the sake of the fat guarantee, and
providing the other team with a
"breather." However, this has not
been done, and the temptation itself

have on the rating of Hopkins teams

the records have been poor on the surface, because Hopkins could play only

chose its teams entirely from the
material which naturally turned out.

Royster rang up goals, and Thaler

started. The rest of the first half,
0. K. 0. was held scoreless while the

Low Scoring
Although both Pi Lambda and Delta
Upsilon have been eliminated from
the pennant race, these teams staged
an important battle for second place
in Division A. Low scoring featured
the game, but Pi Lam finally won
11-10.
Neither team played their usually
isteady game, but throughout the
game the contest was exciting. At
no time did either team hold more
than a two point margin over the
other. D. U. led at the half by a 7-6
score, but Pi Lam came from behind
to cop the game in the last fifteen
minutes of play. Stevens and Bert
Margolis were high scorers with five
points credited to each.
